When you hear scientists tell you things you are inclined to believe them because they have spent a great deal of time studying a problem. And when science is laid against anecdotal evidence anybody offering such evidence is often ridiculed. This leads on to statements like the ones made in this video however when these theories are put into practice they often do not work. In the UK we have been a guinea pig for these experiments and as such have had to suffer various guises of a managed motorway network which is heavily controlled and regulated and claims to reduce driving times by smoothing out the flow of traffic by operating heavily enforced variable speed limits.

So what is the problem; why does it not work when science says it should? Well firstly a number of things have been overlooked:

1 Leaving larger gaps between vehicles reduces the overall capacity of the road.

2 Reducing the speed limit reduces the capacity of the road.

3 The enforcement regime distracts drivers.

As the video says, people will weave in and out of traffic; that is human nature and as we are all inherently selfish (there is nothing wrong with that) we will indeed act like water and travel the easiest and quickest route that we believe is possible. The problem arises in an enforced regime when drivers become frustrated by what they perceive as unnecessary restrictions.

Now perhaps the most flawed example in this video is the bag of rocks; not that it is flawed in its explanation, but it is flawed in being cited as an example of why we should not make roads bigger and wider. In essence it is all about scale. Allow me to go back to my water example which is far more analogous to road traffic than a bag of rocks. Now if you pour water into a funnel then it will slow down, but will not get jammed in the entrance of the funnel; this is because the molecules of the water are small enough and the funnel is large enough to guarantee flow (unless you have a really tiny funnel). The point being that once you make the road wide enough you will reach a point where you do indeed guarantee flow.

The problem of a wave is very real but, certainly in Europe, this is caused by speed restricted vehicles such as heavy goods vehicles being able to use the second lane of motorways when they are artificially restricted to the extent that they cannot travel over 56MPH.

One of the biggest problems that science has in solving the problem is that the problems for long haul and short haul are very different and if the two were separated then it would make life much easier for both. The biggest reason for motorways to become clogged is actual vehicles entering and leaving the motorway (and no amount of active traffic management can do anything about this). One solution is to physically divide the motorway so that a 4 lane motorway could have a couple of long haul lanes and 2 short haul lanes. The long hauls should be physically impossible to exit for around 5 junctions in order to maintain higher speeds which will get vehicles to where they want to be much faster (the faster vehicle go the quicker that they are off the road, which provides a real world increase in overall road capacity). An alternative short term solution would be to block off every other slip road, although this would have a significantly adverse effect on other parts of the road network.

Short haul is a much more difficult problem to solve but in towns and cities making all roads one way and opening up the majority of side roads in order to allow drivers to take a more direct route to their destination would go some way towards alleviating the problem. The problem here is that we need to convince people that they need to accept free flowing traffic going down their side street and that it is not a good idea to let their children and pets play in the road (which lets be honest, it isn't at any speed and flow of traffic).

Automated cars will solve some of the problems, but I think that it is more likely that automated drones will be the real solution (perhaps in 50 or so years time).

Traffic is not hard to fix, traffic is unpopular to fix. All you have to do is to is charge a toll for driving during high demand times sufficient to keep the roads clear enough to move at speed. Then you build a new road if the anticipated value of tolls is large enough.

Why does this work? When you drive, you being on the road makes all the other cars go a little slower, but you don't take that cost into account when you choose when and how to travel. Your private cost of driving is far less than the overall social cost, so you choose the convenience of driving alone over other options like carpooling or mass transit. A good toll system makes you take the social costs of driving into account, since they are now conveyed as private costs, when you evaluate the merits and demerits of various forms of transportation.

We have electronic transponders that can make keeping track of road usage automatic (even a special colour license plate for high volume hours could achieve a lot of the desired effect) and I'm sure a payment scheme could be devised to maintain privacy if that were desired.

Of course, this would be deeply unpopular with the public, so it will probably never happen.
